channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: President Trump is still issuing tariff threats, consumer spending is weakening, and the Mideast is in turmoil. So why did the S&P 500 hit a record high Friday?
item.description: Employers and investors braced for an economic meltdown. It hasn’t happened, though there are headwinds.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: Auto & Transport Roundup: Market Talk
item.description: Find insight on Spirit, Ryanair, European automakers, and more in the latest Market Talks covering Auto and Transport.

item.title: The fallout from the trade war is now showing clearly in Canada’s economy
item.description: The fallout from the trade war is now showing clearly in Canada’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: American households felt more optimistic about the economy in June, though confidence remains lower than it was at the start of the year
item.description: The reading, from the University of Michigan, could show that the initial shock of tariff announcements is wearing off.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: U.S. Jobs Data in Focus as Fed Rate Cuts Loom
item.description: U.S. nonfarm payrolls figures for June will be closely watched because evidence of a weak job market could increase speculation that the Federal Reserve could cut interest rates soon.

item.title: Extreme Poverty Becoming More Concentrated in Conflict Countries, Warns World Bank
item.description: The 39 economies classified as facing conflict or instability are set to be home to 60% of those who live in extreme poverty by 2030.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The Bank of Mexico on Thursday lowered its benchmark interest rate by half of a percentage point in a split vote and left the door open for further cuts
item.description: The central bank lowered its overnight interest-rate target to 8% in split 4-1 vote.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Harrup

item.title: Powell Isn’t Trump’s Only Holdout Against Cuts at a Divided Fed
item.description: Should Fed governors Waller and Bowman both lodge dissenting votes against a committee decision to hold rates steady next month, the tally would show an unusual level of discord.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Conflict in Middle East Might Damp Eurozone Growth, ECB’s De Guindos Says
item.description: Higher energy prices as a result of the Israel-Iran conflict might weaken eurozone economic growth and thus have a damping effect on inflation, the European Central Bank’s vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: After the New York City primaries, look to Texas and other red states for lessons on how to make housing markets work, @greg_ip writes
item.description: Austin, Texas, and other red-state cities have set an example for how to make housing markets work.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: German Consumers Grow More Cautious as Confidence Slips
item.description: Sentiment edged lower for the first time in four months as households opted to boost savings, despite greater optimism surrounding their income prospects.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: President Trump’s exasperation over the Fed’s take-it-slow approach to cutting rates is prompting him to consider accelerating when he will announce his pick to succeed Chair Jerome Powell
item.description: Kevin Warsh, Kevin Hassett and Scott Bessent are among those under consideration as Trump evaluates their commitment to cutting rates—and “made-for-TV” appeal.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: U.S. New Home Sales Slump as High Mortgage Rates Persist
item.description: Sales of new homes fell 13.7% to 623,000 in May amid continued concerns over high mortgage costs.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Homeowners who bought around the peak of the market are increasingly finding they owe more on their mortgages than their properties are worth
item.description: Some who bought around the market peak in pandemic boomtowns owe more on their mortgages than their homes are worth.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Stamm

item.title: ECB’s Challenge Is to Ensure Short-Term Price Shifts Don’t Become Long-Lasting, Says Lane
item.description: Policymakers have to make sure the medium-term inflation target is protected in a volatile environment, the ECB’s chief economist says.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The Conference Board’s June consumer-confidence index fell to 93, from 98.4 in May, surprising analysts
item.description: U.S. consumer confidence slipped in June, reversing an improvement in May, according to the Conference Board.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.S. Home Price Growth Cools to Near-Two-Year Low
item.description: U.S. home prices rose at the slowest annual pace in nearly two years as mortgage prices continued to stretch affordability.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Global Business Remains Resilient in Face of Tariffs, Middle East War
item.description: Business activity in the U.S., Europe and some large economies in Asia continued to grow this month despite continued uncertainty about global trade policy and the threat of higher energy prices as conflict in the Middle East intensifies.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The ECB president says impairment of oil-and-gas transit could pressure a range of prices, not just those of the affected commodities
item.description: A reduction in the flow of oil and gas through the strait could push a range of prices higher, a threat that policymakers are monitoring closely, the head of the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Sales of existing homes rose slightly in May but held near historically low levels, the latest sign that buyers are staying away because of high home prices
item.description: Sales of existing homes held near historically low levels, the latest sign that buyers are staying away because of high home prices.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Tariffs left an Illinois toy maker weeks to move equipment out of China. Then came the U.S.-China trade deal and a court victory. ‘No one’s going to save me,’ the CEO said.
item.description: CEO Rick Woldenberg is moving equipment out of China, saying that “no one’s going to save me.”
item.dc:creator: Theo Francis

item.title: The U.S. and EU appear to be nearing a deal on multiple non-tariff trade issues from deforestation rules to the treatment of U.S. tech companies in Europe
item.description: A draft agreement on reciprocal trade touches a litany of economic disputes between the economies—but not tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: Almost a Third of Eurozone’s U.S. Trade Surplus Is Due to U.S. Firms, Says ECB
item.description: Affiliates of American businesses also account for most of the eurozone’s deficit in the trade in services, the European Central Bank said Friday.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Consumer Sentiment Edges Up Again Despite Global Turbulence
item.description: The uptick was likely fuelled by easing price inflation and a cut to interest rates in May.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Canada imposes import curbs on steel to address fallout from Trump tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Carney said the policy changes address ‘destabilization’ of metals sector due to U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Foreign Investment Faces Third Year of Decline on Tariff Uncertainty, UN Warns
item.description: Overseas investment by businesses around the world is at risk of falling for a third straight year as rising tariffs and geopolitical tensions freeze big decisions about where to locate factories, the UN warned.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Irish Central Bank Warns U.S. Policy Changes Could Lead to Slower Growth, Higher Debt
item.description: The rise in U.S. tariffs announced in early April would have a significant impact on economic growth over coming years, the central bank said in its quarterly outlook.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: President Trump left the Group of Seven summit in Canada a day early without new trade deals, after signing onto a joint statement that calls for peace and stability in the Middle East
item.description: The president didn’t reach new trade deals but signed onto a joint statement calling for “peace and stability.”
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: It’s a bad time to be a job seeker—especially if you are young
item.description: Slow hiring is especially daunting for those just starting out. “Right now, I’m pretending employment doesn’t exist,” says a recent college graduate.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: Consumers are making spending decisions in the fog of trade war, uncertain about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation of companies’ push for more profits
item.description: Consumers are making spending decisions in a haze of uncertainty about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation or companies’ push for more profits.
item.dc:creator: Joe Pinsker

item.title: Is the immigration crackdown already showing up in the labor market?
item.description: There are hints that the number of migrants in the U.S. labor force is already declining. It will take time, though, for the full effects to show up.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Timms

item.title: U.S. job growth slowed slightly last month, a sign employers grew more cautious about hiring
item.description: The U.S. added 139,000 jobs in May, and the unemployment rate held steady at 4.2%.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Early hints of a slowing labor market are raising the stakes for Friday’s release of the May jobs report, anticipated to show cooler hiring but a steady unemployment rate
item.description: Analysts polled by The Wall Street Journal are expecting the Labor Department’s report to show that the U.S. added a net 125,000 jobs in May.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Labor-Market Outlook Cautious Ahead of May Jobs Report
item.description: Early hints of a slowing labor market are raising the stakes for Friday’s release of the May jobs report, anticipated to show cooler hiring but a steady unemployment rate.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May was 50.8, down about 3% from a final reading of 52.2 in April
item.description: The University of Michigan’s closely watched consumer-sentiment index was 50.8 in preliminary numbers for May.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos
